title: What is a simple partial differential equation? - Quora

response.answer_text:
Probably the simplest and one of the first you encounter is the Laplacian [math]
abla^2  B=0 [/math] Which in Cartesian coordinates is [math] rac{\partial^2 B}{\partial x^2 }+ rac{\partial^2 B}{\partial y^2 }+ rac{\partial^2 B}{\partial z^2 }=0 [/math] One easy solution is [math]B=xyz[/math] If you've studied vector calculus, you'd recognize this as the divergence of the gradient [math]
abla \cdot 
abla B=0[/math] In physics, this is a special case of the diffusion equation when the system is in equilibrium, I e. [math]
abla^2 B= rac{\partial B}{\partial t}[/math] where [math]t[/math] is time. If B were a temperature for example, the pde models the evolution of a the scalar feild temperature of that solid over time. If it is in equilibrium , the first -order time derivative is 0. Then we only need boundary conditions to complete, e.g.. B(0,x,y) =w, B(100, x,y) =u, and so forth to find the interesting solution.

On [math]\mathbb{R}^n[/math], we set [math]\dfrac{\partial^n u}{\partial x_1 \partial x_2 \cdots \partial x_n}=0.\tag*{}[/math] This PDE is an easy and simple one. Without complicating things and instead of dealing with [math]n[/math] variables, we just pick two. So, on [math]\mathbb{R}^2[/math], the PDE [math]\dfrac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x\partial y}=0, \tag{1}[/math] has the following solution [math]u(x,y)=A(x)+B(y), \tag*{}[/math] for any two-times differentiable functions [math]A[/math] and [math]B[/math]. That is, the functions [math]u_1(x,y)=\alpha x+y, \alpha\in\mathbb{R},\tag*{}[/math] [math]u_2(x,y)=e^x+e^{-2 y}, \tag*{}[/math] [math]u_3(x,y)=\cosh(x-6)-5 \sin(\pi y), \tag*{}[/math] are all solutions to [math](1)[/math] in [math]\mathbb{R}^2[/math].
